title: The Translator
description: A war crimes tribunal. The witness speaks a dialect you barely know.

scenes.title: The Booth
scenes.content:
The headphones crackle. Static, then a voice I almost recognize.

"Witness will state his name for the record."

The old man leans into the microphone. His words come out in Bosnian, but twisted. Rural. Mountain dialect from somewhere I can't place. My fingers hover over the keyboard.

"Mehmed Hadzic," he says. Then something else. Something about his village.

Judge Morrison waits. The prosecutor taps her pen. In the gallery, families of victims lean forward. Reporters check their phones.

My voice goes into the system, crisp and professional: "The witness states his name as Mehmed Hadzic."

But he said more. Something about the old road, the one that wound past the cemetery. I caught maybe half of it. The other translator, Vera, is handling Serbian today. She's not listening to this channel.

The witness shifts in his chair. His hands shake. He's maybe seventy, wearing a suit that doesn't fit right. Behind his glasses, his eyes dart between the judges and the defendant.

Defendant Marković sits perfectly still. His lawyer whispers something. The witness sees this. His jaw tightens.

choices.text: Ask for clarification through the court officer
Signal the other translator for help

scenes.title: Official Channels
scenes.content:
I press the interpreter button. Red light flashes on my console.

"Your Honor, the interpreter requests clarification from the witness regarding his statement."

Judge Morrison looks up. "What seems to be the issue?"

"The witness spoke in a regional dialect. I want to ensure accuracy."

The judge nods to the court officer. "Please ask the witness to repeat his statement more slowly."

The witness looks confused when the officer explains. His attorney leans over, speaks to him in careful, formal Bosnian. The witness nods but his expression changes. More guarded now.

"Mehmed Hadzic," he says again. "From Gorazde."

That's not what he said before. The word he used was older, local. A village name that probably doesn't exist on any current map. But now he's giving the official answer, the one that fits into court records.

I translate exactly what he says this time. Clean. Proper. Wrong.

The prosecutor continues. "Mr. Hadzic, can you tell us about the events of July 15th, 1995?"

choices.text: Note the discrepancy in your files

scenes.title: Missing Words
scenes.content:
I translate what I can understand. Leave gaps where the dialect gets too thick.

The testimony moves forward. Hadzic describes the morning. Soldiers coming to the village. His voice gets stronger as he talks, more animated. The mountain dialect creeps back in.

"They separated the men," I translate. "Made us line up by the school."

But he's saying something else too. About a commander with a scar. About dogs barking in the distance. About his nephew crying. The words blur together in a rhythm I remember from somewhere else.

The prosecutor shows him a photograph. Hadzic studies it, nods.

"That's him," he says in clear Bosnian. Then adds something rapid, dialect-heavy.

I catch fragments. Brother. Promise. The winter when the river froze.

"The witness identifies the subject in the photograph," I say into my microphone.

Defendant Marković's lawyer stands. "Objection. The witness said more than that."

Judge Morrison looks toward my booth. The red recording light blinks steadily. Everything I say becomes part of the permanent record.

choices.text: Admit you missed part of the statement
State that the witness only confirmed the identification

scenes.title: Vera's Assistance
scenes.content:
I catch Vera's eye through the glass partition. Tap my headphones, point to the witness. She frowns, puts on the Bosnian channel.

Hadzic continues talking. About his village, his family. Vera scribbles notes on a pad, holds it up: "Rozanj dialect - mountain region."

I've heard it before. Not here in The Hague, but in another place, another time. A checkpoint outside Sarajevo. A woman begging for safe passage, using the same lilting vowels, the same dropped consonants.

Vera writes more: "He's talking about the old cemetery road."

The prosecutor asks about July 15th. Hadzic's story pours out, detailed and devastating. Twenty-three men lined up against the school wall. His brother among them. Commander Marković walking down the line, making selections.

I translate steadily now, with Vera's help filling the gaps. But something bothers me. The way Hadzic describes the commander. The scar that runs from ear to jaw. The gold tooth in front.

I saw that scar once. Up close. Close enough to smell cigarettes and plum brandy on his breath.

"Did the defendant speak to any of the prisoners?" the prosecutor asks.

choices.text: Pay closer attention to descriptions of Marković

scenes.title: Clean Record
scenes.content:
The testimony proceeds smoothly now. Hadzic sticks to standard Bosnian, speaks slowly. His lawyer must have coached him well.

He describes the massacre methodically. Names, dates, locations. Everything the prosecution needs for their case. I translate each word precisely.

But something is lost. The texture of his memory. The way he originally spoke about his village, with love and specificity. Now it's just "Gorazde region" and "rural community."

During the lunch recess, I see him in the hallway with his attorney. They're speaking in whispers, but I catch fragments. The lawyer is telling him to be careful, to stick to the prepared statements.

"The judges need clarity," the lawyer says. "Not poetry."

Hadzic nods, but his shoulders are slumped. He looks smaller somehow.

When court resumes, the defense begins cross-examination. They attack his memory, his timeline, the distance from which he observed events. Hadzic answers carefully, precisely. Every response translates cleanly.

The lawyer presses harder. "How can you be certain of what you saw from 200 meters away?"

Hadzic hesitates. His mouth opens, closes. He wants to explain something but can't find the words in formal Bosnian.

scenes.title: Personal Notes
scenes.content:
I keep a separate notebook. Not part of the official record. Just for me.

"Witness originally said village name: sounds like 'Rozanije' or 'Rozanj.' Changed to 'Gorazde' after clarification."

The testimony continues. I translate the sanitized version but track the discrepancies. When Hadzic talks about his brother, he uses a childhood nickname first, then switches to the formal name. When he describes the commander, his dialect gets thicker, more emotional.

At the lunch break, I research the region. Find references to Rozanj in old Austrian maps. A village that was absorbed into Gorazde municipality in the 1960s. Probably three hundred people, maybe fewer.

The afternoon session focuses on identification. The prosecution shows photographs, documents. Hadzic identifies defendant Marković without hesitation.

"That's the man who gave the orders," he says clearly.

But in dialect, he adds something else. Something about promises made and broken. About winter nights when there was no food.

I translate the identification. Keep the rest in my notes.

After court, I walk back to the hotel through The Hague's orderly streets. My notebook feels heavy in my briefcase. Full of words that will never make it into the official record.

scenes.title: Confession
scenes.content:
"Your Honor, I need to clarify. The witness added additional remarks that I was unable to fully translate due to dialectical variations."

The courtroom stirs. Lawyers whisper to each other. Judge Morrison leans forward.

"What exactly did you miss, Interpreter?"

My throat feels dry. "The witness spoke about personal details regarding the identified subject. Family connections, possibly. The regional dialect made it difficult to be certain of the meaning."

The defense attorney pounces. "Your Honor, if the court's interpreter cannot accurately translate the witness's statements, how can we rely on any of this testimony?"

Judge Morrison calls a recess. Court officers escort Hadzic out while the lawyers argue procedure. I sit in my booth, headphones off, watching the chaos I've created.

Vera slides her partition open. "What are you doing?"

"My job."

"Your job is to translate, not to stop the trial."

When court resumes, they've found a second interpreter. Someone who specializes in regional dialects. Hadzic will have to repeat his identification testimony.

He looks tired now. Older. But when he speaks again, it's in his natural voice.

choices.text: Listen carefully to the new translation
Pack up and leave the booth

scenes.title: Filling Gaps
scenes.content:
"The witness said: 'That's him. That's the man who promised my brother safe passage if he cooperated. The winter the river froze, he said the killings would stop.'"

Silence in the courtroom. The defense attorney objects immediately, but Judge Morrison overrules.

"The interpreter will provide complete translations going forward."

Hadzic stares at me through the witness booth glass. He nods slightly, understanding that someone finally heard his full words.

The prosecutor follows up. "Mr. Hadzic, you mentioned promises made to your brother. Can you elaborate?"

This time, Hadzic speaks slowly, clearly. The dialect is still there but controlled now. He knows I'm listening for everything.

He describes private conversations. Deals offered and broken. A commander who spoke to prisoners individually, learning their names, their families, before deciding who lived or died.

Defendant Marković sits rigid. His lawyer scribbles furious notes.

"The defendant told my brother he would be relocated, not harmed," Hadzic continues. "He shook his hand. Called him by name."

I translate every word. The emotional weight. The personal betrayal. Not just war crimes, but individual acts of deception.

scenes.title: Standing Firm
scenes.content:
"The witness confirmed the identification of the subject in the photograph. Nothing further was stated."

The defense attorney presses. "Are you certain? The witness appeared to speak for several more seconds."

"I translate substance, not stammering or repetition."

It's a reasonable explanation. Witnesses often repeat themselves, add meaningless filler. The lawyer sits down, but his expression suggests he's not convinced.

Hadzic watches this exchange. His face is unreadable, but his hands grip the witness stand edge.

The testimony continues. More photographs, more identifications. I stick to clear, factual translations. When dialect creeps in, I render it in standard form. When emotional language appears, I moderate it to legal terminology.

"He destroyed our lives" becomes "The defendant caused harm to the community."

"He looked my brother in the eyes before he gave the order" becomes "The defendant appeared to recognize the victim."

By the end of the day, the transcript reads like a police report. Clean, useful, accurate in its way. The prosecution has what they need for conviction.

But Hadzic leaves the witness stand looking emptied out. As if something essential was taken from him.

scenes.title: Professional Distance
scenes.content:
I focus on the words, not the memories they trigger. This is my job. Neutral transmission of meaning across languages.

Hadzic describes the selection process. How Marković walked the line of prisoners, choosing who would work and who would die. His voice stays steady until he reaches his brother's name.

"Emir was nineteen. A student. He spoke some German, so they thought he might be useful."

The prosecutor asks for more details. Hadzic provides them methodically. Age, occupation, physical description. I translate each fact precisely.

But I can't stop watching defendant Marković. The way he takes notes during testimony. The way he whispers to his lawyer when certain names come up. The way his hand moves to his throat when Hadzic describes the scar.

Fourteen years ago, outside Sarajevo, a checkpoint commander with that same scar let my press convoy through. Waved us past a line of detained civilians. Said something about journalists needing to "tell the true story."

I never wrote that story. Never mentioned the people we left behind.

The prosecutor shows video evidence now. Grainy footage from the village. I don't need to see it to know what it shows.

scenes.title: Recognition
scenes.content:
When Hadzic describes the scar, I remember.

Checkpoint Seven, outside Sarajevo. Summer 1995. Our press convoy stopped for document inspection. The commander was polite, almost charming. Spoke good English.

"You are here to report the truth?" he asked, examining our credentials.

Behind him, soldiers guarded a group of civilians. Maybe thirty people sitting in the dust, hands zip-tied behind their backs. I asked about them.

"Relocations," he said. "Standard procedure."

He had gold teeth. A scar from ear to jaw. Kind eyes that didn't match his uniform.

We drove away. I never followed up on what happened to those people.

Now, listening to Hadzic testify, I understand. Those weren't relocations. They were selections. And the man sitting in the defendant's chair is the same one who smiled and waved us through that checkpoint.

Marković notices me staring. Our eyes meet through the booth glass. For just a moment, his composed expression flickers. Recognition.

He remembers journalists too. Remembers witnesses who might have seen too much.

Hadzic is still talking. About promises and betrayals. About personal conversations with the commander before the killings began.

choices.text: Continue translating as if nothing happened
Report what you witnessed at the checkpoint

scenes.title: Truth Revealed
scenes.content:
The new interpreter works slowly, carefully. Her voice is different from mine. Older. More weathered.

She has Hadzic repeat his identification. This time, the full translation comes through:

"That's Milan Marković. He knew my family. Before the war, he dated my cousin Amira. He came to our wedding celebrations. Danced with our grandmother. When he walked down the line that morning, he called us each by name."

The courtroom is absolutely silent.

"He told my brother: 'Emir, you always were the smart one. Don't worry, we'll find work for you.' Then he nodded to the soldiers. They took Emir with the others. To the pit behind the school."

The prosecutor asks if he's certain about these details.

"I am certain. You don't forget the voice of someone who sang at your wedding before he murdered your family."

Defendant Marković slumps in his chair. His lawyer calls for recess, but Judge Morrison denies the motion.

I sit in my empty booth, listening to testimony I should have translated hours ago. The truth I kept locked behind dialectical difficulties and professional caution.

Sometimes precision means more than accuracy. Sometimes it means courage.

scenes.title: Dangerous Knowledge
scenes.content:
I translate Hadzic's remaining testimony without meeting Marković's eyes again. Professional. Neutral. Invisible.

But during the afternoon recess, court security approaches my booth.

"Sir, defendant's counsel would like to speak with you about potential testimony."

My blood goes cold. They can't compel interpreter testimony about unrelated events. But they can make life difficult.

I gather my things, shut down my equipment. In the hallway, Marković's lawyer waits.

"You look familiar," he says. "Have we met before? Perhaps during the conflict years?"

It's not really a question.

"I don't think so."

"No? Interesting. My client thought he recognized you. Said you might have covered some of the checkpoint operations for international media."

He hands me his card. "If you remember anything about those days, we'd be very interested in your perspective. Professional journalists saw a lot of things. Sometimes memory needs refreshing."

That evening, my hotel room feels smaller. The curtains stay drawn. CNN plays on mute, showing other conflicts in other countries.

Tomorrow, Hadzic continues his testimony. I'll translate his words exactly as he speaks them. Nothing more.
